title: How to Measure a Bolt Pattern

steps.title: Park the vehicle and turn off the engine.
steps.content: Park the vehicle and turn off the engine. You don’t want your vehicle or trailer to move while you’re measuring the bolt pattern! Park it in a flat area and engage the emergency brake so it’s stable and won’t move. [1] X Research source If you’re measuring the bolt pattern for a vehicle that doesn’t have wheels, like a parts car in a junkyard or a repair shop, make sure it’s either stable on the ground or secure on a jack stand . Make sure your trailer is secure before you measure its bolt pattern.

steps.title: Use a screwdriver to remove the hubcap from 1 of the tires.
steps.content: Use a screwdriver to remove the hubcap from 1 of the tires. The wheels on your vehicle may have a cap over the hub that covers and protects the lug nuts. Take a flat-head screwdriver and wedge it in between the outer edge of the hubcap and the rim. Apply gentle pressure to pry off the hubcap. [2] X Research source You only need to remove the hubcap from 1 tire, because all of the wheel hubs on your vehicle will be the same. You may be able to see the lug nuts without removing the hubcap. If that’s the case, then don’t worry about removing the hubcap.

steps.title: Count all of the bolts in the pattern.
steps.content: Count all of the bolts in the pattern. In the center of the wheel, you’ll see a circle of large, rounded nuts covering heavy-duty bolts. These are the lug nuts and they keep the wheel attached to your vehicle. Count the total number of bolts with lug nuts that you see. [3] X Research source Most vehicles will have either 4, 5, 6, or 8 lug nuts.

steps.title: Keep the lug nuts exposed so you can measure them.
steps.content: Keep the lug nuts exposed so you can measure them. After you’ve removed the hubcap from 1 tire and counted the number of lug nuts, keep the hubcap off of the tire for now. You don’t want to have to remove it again when you go to measure the bolt pattern. [4] X Research source You only need to leave the lug nuts of 1 tire exposed.

steps.title: Measure the distance between 2 parallel lug nuts for wheels with an even number of bolts.
steps.content: Measure the distance between 2 parallel lug nuts for wheels with an even number of bolts. If your wheel has an even number of bolts, then take a tape measure and measure from the center of 1 lug nut to the center of the lug nut directly across from it. [5] X Research source Regardless of how many lug nuts your wheel has, if it’s an even number, you can measure the diameter this way. For example, you could have a measurement of 205 millimetres (8.1 in) from the center of 1 lug nut to another.

steps.title: Find the distance from the top of 1 lug nut to the center of another for wheels with odd-numbered bolts.
steps.content: Find the distance from the top of 1 lug nut to the center of another for wheels with odd-numbered bolts. If your wheel has 5 bolts, or another odd number of bolts, measure from the very top of 1 lug nut to the center of the bolt that is directly across from it in order to find the diameter. [6] X Research source A common measurement for a 5 bolt pattern is 120 millimetres (4.7 in) from the top of 1 lug to the center of another.

steps.title: Use a bolt circle template for a convenient alternative.
steps.content: Use a bolt circle template for a convenient alternative. If you want to have the most accurate measurement, use a bolt circle template. They’re inexpensive and easy to use. Slide the template over the studs and read the size markings on it. [7] X Research source Use a tire iron to remove the lug nuts to expose the bolts before you use the bolt circle template. You don’t need to jack up the vehicle or trailer because you’re not removing the tire to take your measurement. You can find bolt circle templates at auto supply stores or online.

steps.title: Combine the number of bolts and the diameter to get a measurement.
steps.content: Combine the number of bolts and the diameter to get a measurement. Take the 2 numbers and separate them with an “x” to create the measurement that you can use to get the right wheels for your vehicle or trailer. Provide the diameter in either inches or millimeters, depending on where you purchase your wheels. [8] X Research source An example bolt pattern size could look like: 4 x 130 millimetres (5.1 in). That means the vehicle has 4 bolt holes and a diameter of 130 millimetres (5.1 in).
